name: Selective Sensor-Based Health Oversight
description: This use case enables tailored health monitoring through wearable sensors while respecting the older adult's strict privacy preferences and interaction style. It supports formal, controlled communication and personalized care coordination between Olivia and her nurse Mike, balancing effective health oversight with the user's need for autonomy and minimal notifications.
scenario:
Olivia sat quietly in her living room, her fingers hesitating over the push-to-talk button on the ALFRED device. She disliked how technology often felt intrusive, so she insisted on initiating all interactions herself. “ALFRED, please report my vital signs,” she said softly, her voice steady but cautious. The system complied, retrieving data only from the minimal set of sensors she reluctantly wore—carefully selected to avoid sharing with anyone beyond her nurse, Mike. Olivia’s privacy settings were stringent; she blocked all app installations, turned off nearly all notifications, and forbade any informal communication or casual chatting.

Meanwhile, Mike Johnson, working a hectic shift at the city hospital, logged into ALFRED’s caregiver interface. He scanned Olivia’s sparse health data with a mix of frustration and professional concern. The limited information hampered his ability to detect subtle changes in her condition, but he knew pushing for more data would only alienate Olivia further. Mike preferred quick, clinical updates without non-essential alerts, so he had configured ALFRED to mute all non-critical notifications during his shifts. He hoped Olivia would accept at least a video check-in, but she had firmly declined, insisting on offline visits at her home only. Mike sighed, aware that despite his desire for comprehensive oversight, he had to respect her privacy—even if it made his job harder.

When Olivia felt uneasy about a slight dizziness episode, she hesitated before pressing the button. “ALFRED, notify Nurse Mike that I need a home visit,” she said, her tone formal and measured. The system confirmed the message, ensuring the communication remained strictly professional and devoid of casual language. Mike received the notification shortly after his shift ended and arranged an in-person visit, appreciating Olivia’s control over timing and method of contact.

Throughout the day, ALFRED remained mostly silent, honoring Olivia’s preference for minimal interaction and no unsolicited prompts. Olivia found comfort in this restraint, though Mike struggled to balance his clinical responsibilities with the limits imposed by her autonomy. Their relationship with ALFRED was marked by tension: Olivia’s guarded independence and deep distrust of technology clashed with Mike’s need for timely, detailed health data. Yet, through ALFRED’s adaptable design, they maintained a fragile but functional connection—each uneasy but respectful of the other’s boundaries.
